docs.snippet: After the paper's Gold Derby blog made a case for an "Inglourious Basterds" Oscar, Patrick Goldstein served up a bristling counterpoint....
docs.lead_paragraph: There is trouble in Oscar pundit land. The Bagger knows you'll be shocked (shocked!) to find that there is a brouhaha over something Harvey Weinstein-related, namely his campaign to get "Inglourious Basterds" into the conversation for best picture.
docs.abstract: After the paper's Gold Derby blog made a case for an "Inglourious Basterds" Oscar, Patrick Goldstein served up a bristling counterpoint.

headline.main: Intramural Squabbling at The L.A. Times

docs.snippet: The Iraq war movie dominated at the Baftas on Sunday, but the British Oscars do not have a great track record at predicting the eventual best picture winner....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Baftas, a.k.a. the British Oscars, should provide some cold comfort to awards-season watchers. On the one hand, "The Hurt Locker," this year's hard-charging underdog, swept the prizes on Sunday, picking up six of its eight races, including best picture, best director and best original screenplay. On the other, the British cinephiles have predicted the eventual best picture Oscar winner only three times in the nine years since their little show has been held before the Academy Awards. So as Harvey Weinstein would like to remind you, it ain't over yet for "Inglourious Basterds" (no matter how seemingly unlikely).
docs.abstract: The Iraq war movie dominated at the Baftas on Sunday, but the British Oscars do not have a great track record at predicting the eventual best picture winner.

headline.main: Cold Comfort for 'Hurt Locker' in London

docs.snippet: Awards season is in full swing at home and abroad....
docs.lead_paragraph: Awards season is in full swing at home and abroad.

docs.snippet: As usual, the L.A. awards were starrier, but the show in New York, hosted by Susie Essman, were more profane....
docs.lead_paragraph: Despite being held simultaneously on both coasts to add drama, there were few surprises for statuette-counters at the Writers Guild Awards on Saturday night. "Up in the Air," "The Hurt Locker" and "The Cove," favorites all season long, won for best adapted screenplay, best original screenplay and best documentary, respectively, and the winners gave variations on the speeches they've been giving all season long. In Los Angeles, Jason Reitman, of "Up in the Air," thanked his father, Ivan; his co-writer, Sheldon Turner, thanked other writers. And "The Hurt Locker" writer Mark Boal thanked Kathryn Bigelow, the director, for "believing in an unpopular project about an unpopular war." In New York, the Bagger's pal Anthony Mackie rushed over from his curtain call at "A Behanding in Spokane" on Broadway to accept the award on Mr. Boal's behalf, doing a not-very-convincing impression of him.
docs.abstract: As usual, the L.A. awards were starrier, but the show in New York, hosted by Susie Essman, were more profane.

headline.main: Bicoastal Dissonance at Unsurprising Writers Guild Awards

docs.snippet: Hong Kong has a bit of an inferiority complex when it comes to its arts scene, so when it puts on a festival, it sometimes overcompensates by throwing in everything including the kitchen sink. The lineup at this year's Hong Kong Arts Festival, whi...
docs.lead_paragraph: Hong Kong has a bit of an inferiority complex when it comes to its arts scene, so when it puts on a festival, it sometimes overcompensates by throwing in everything including the kitchen sink. The lineup at this year's Hong Kong Arts Festival, which starts on Thursday, Feb. 25, and runs through March 28, is a testament to that, but no matter -- the upside is, there is something for everyone.
docs.abstract: Hong Kong has a bit of an inferiority complex when it comes to its arts scene, so when it puts on a festival, it sometimes overcompensates by throwing in everything including the kitchen sink. The lineup at this year's Hong Kong Arts Festival, which starts on Feb. 25 and runs through March 28, is a testament to that, but no matter -- the upside is, there is something for everyone.

headline.main: The Arts, From A to Z, at Hong Kong Festival

DeMille Award for lifetime achievement.
